previewPlan.name: Mallorca 312 - 6 Weeks (2024)
previewPlan.description:
Prepare for Mallorca 312 with a Wahoo X training plan.

This plan incorporates Yoga and Mental Training to prepare your mind and body for the epic demands of the Mallorca 312.
previewPlan.planDescription: Everything needed to complete the 2024 Mallorca 312

prospects.name: 02. Identifying Your Personal Big Mountain
prospects.description:
What - exactly - are you trying to accomplish? When you're ready to answer that question, this module will help you gain clarity on who you are as an athlete and identify your major goal—your Personal Big Mountain.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[The Importance of SMART Goal Setting](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/start-now-goal-setting-basics)' and '[How to use your personal outlook to set more effective goals](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/know-thyself-how-to-use-your-personal-outlook-to-set-more-effective-goals)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: The Cure
prospects.description:
Do you have Couchlandrian Tendencies? This short but powerful workout will cure you of that affliction and reassert your inner Sufferlandrian. The session is based on a combination of specific micro-intervals (made famous by Japanese coach and physiologist Izumi Tabata) that we combined with classic tempo efforts. This gives you a superb mix of Anaerobic Capacity (AC), Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and FTP training stresses in one short workout to help you go faster and stay stronger for longer.

​

Now, for the sports science purists among you, the 'Tabata' intervals should actually be named 'Koichi' intervals, since it was Japanese speedskating coach Irisawa Koichi who first employed the use of the 20-seconds on / 10-seconds off intervals that Dr. Izumi then confirmed via physiology lab studies to yield the best mix of maximal aerobic and anaerobic stress among the different on/off protocols that he tested.

​

For this workout, we have toned down the original intensity of the Tabata intervals to target MAP rather than Anaerobic Capacity in order to be able to complete the 20/10 micro-intervals and then follow the short efforts immediately with sustained 80-100% of FTP intervals to replicate the kind of attack and then settle efforts that are common in cycling races.

​

From a physiological perspective, you’ll produce lots of lactate during the micro-intervals. Then the goal of the tempo and FTP efforts is to stress your body’s capacity to clear that lactate as quickly as possible. Effectively, we’re trying to maximize lactate 'flux.' For each successive round of the efforts, you’ll do one less micro-interval, and the tempo efforts will get shorter. But because you’re a Sufferlandrian, they won’t get easier, and the rest between sets will get shorter. The intensity for the tempo efforts will ramp up with each repetition. Fortunately for you, there are only 3 sets of efforts and you’ll be done in just 30 minutes. If you’ve set aside an hour for this workout, you’ll be happy to have those additional 30 minutes for recovery after this session.

prospects.name: The Soul of a Cyclist
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Directed by Nuno Tavares, The Soul of a Cyclist revolves around the subject of classic bicycles**. **Shot in Portugal and in England, the film captures personal experiences of individuals who own and ride classic bicycles and their deep connection with them. A film full of curiosity, joy and adventure.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Total Newbie Yoga
prospects.description: Yoga-curious but don't know where to start? This session is a great place to dip your toes in. This easy, basic routine will introduce you to some simple foundational moves while giving you a little stretch and some light strength work at the same time. Think of it as the gateway drug to bringing yoga into your life.

prospects.name: Bavaria: Burgberg
prospects.description:
This may be a short workout, but it packs a serious punch—so lace up those gloves and get ready for 22 powerful 10-second seated sprints!

After a gentle warm-up leaving the picturesque village of Sulzberg, we’ll dive straight into our first block: 8 x 10-second high-cadence seated sprints with 50 seconds of recovery.

As the road naturally levels out, we’ll catch our breath before hitting the core of the workout—9 x 10-second low-cadence seated sprints with the same 50-second recovery, focusing on maintaining rock-solid form.

To close things out, we’ll return to the high-cadence style for a final round of 5 x 10-second sprints. This session is designed to sharpen muscle activation and improve recovery after intense efforts.

Finish strong, and I’ll see you in Burgberg!

​

With short near-maximal sprint efforts like these, you’ll recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal power. Just like cadence builds, this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system.

Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down efficiency effect to the longer-duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9866624296)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Tasmania: Cygnet Coast Road
prospects.description:
The setting might be one of stunning tranquility, but this workout certainly isn't. We're down in far, far Southern Tasmania for a ride along one of the most stunning - but little known - roads in the region. Starting in the hamlet of Cradoc, we head south along the peninsula to the village of Cygnet. It's a rolling road with countless little 'kickers' that we're going to hit at maximum intensity in order to simulate a race or hard group ride. Along the way, we'll pop in to visit some of the most interesting characters who call this area home: a winemaker, an artist, and the founder of a famous cooking school.

​

[Route on Strava](https://www.strava.com/routes/2927502558987635926)

​

_About your host: Who better to show you around Tasmania than Nicole Frain? Raised in the north of the island, and currently living just outside Hobart, Nicole knows all the best places to spend your time on and off the bike. Known for her aggressive racing, the Parkhotel-Valkenberg professional won the 2022 Australian Elite Road Race Championship with a late attack and also finished second overall at the 2022 Tour Down Under. Good luck staying with her as she takes you through these workouts!_

​

Featured in this video:

[Farmhouse Kitchen](https://www.thefarmhousekitchen-tas.com/)

[Sailor Seeks Horse](https://sailorseekshorse.com.au/)

[Matt Calvert](https://mattcalvert.com.au/)

prospects.name: MAP: 2 Sets 8 x 1
prospects.description:
The goal of this session is to accumulate a significant amount of time near your VO2max, or the point at which your body is consuming as much oxygen as it possibly can. That means your heart rate and breathing rate will both be near their max by the end of each interval, especially in the final few intervals.

​

Since it takes time for your heart rate and breathing rate to match your effort, for the first part of each interval, you will be tapping into your Anaerobic Capacity to produce the required power. To account for this, we have limited the recovery duration to be equal to the interval duration. Limited recovery ensures that you will drain your Anaerobic Capacity before the end of the intervals, meaning your body will be forced to produce as much power as possible using oxygen.

​

**Warm-Up**

15 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- 90%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-180% of FTP)

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 2

Rest Between Sets: 2 hours @ RPE 4 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 8

**Interval **

Effort: 1 minutes @ RPE 9 -- 90-110% of MAP (115-135% of FTP)

Recovery: 1 minutes @ RPE 2 -- <45% of FTP

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Endurance  4
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

​

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 11

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 1

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: 07. Positive Self-Talk
prospects.description:
Improve your confidence and performance through three types of positive self-talk: Motivational, Instructional, and Reward. Here, we’ll look at the subtle and not-so-subtle effects that words have on our attitude and performance. You’ll listen more closely to the way you talk to yourself so you can improve that internal dialogue and become your own biggest fan.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[The Power of Positive Mental Strategies](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/episode-29-how-to-use-positive-self-talk-to-get-through-tough-moments-on-a-ride-mental-strategies)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Fitness.

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Bavaria: Oberjoch
prospects.description:
Saddle up and prepare to conquer Oberjoch, the signature climb of the region, taking us through Bavaria’s lush pastures towards Austria’s scenic Lake Haldensee.

​

This workout features a series of low and high cadence drills with a progressive intensity build. We’ll kick off the climb with a 4-minute low cadence interval at 80-85% FTP, followed by a 2-minute recovery. From there, each interval shortens by one minute, while the cadence and effort increase slightly, alternating between low and high cadence to maintain focus and form.

Once we reach the summit, it’s time to recover briefly before diving into the second part of the session: five 60-second tempo-to-threshold builds on the flat toward Haldensee. This workout is designed to improve aerobic efficiency, strength, and your ability to recover between hard efforts. Sounds simple? Let’s chat at the end—good luck!

​

The intervals will alternate between low and high cadence requiring you to ride at an exceptionally low cadence to stress your muscular system more than your cardiovascular system and then riding at 100+ RPM has the exact opposite effect with less strain on your muscles, but a greater strain on your cardiovascular system. Alternating back and forth between low and high cadence will ensure both your muscular system and cardiovascular system get pushed hard.

The tempo builds will work you hard but flush out your legs making your recovery quicker so you can go hard tomorrow.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9853644571)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Serenity
prospects.description:
Starting at the islands iconic rainbow rocks at Los Azulejos de Veneguera in this session we tackle one of the most stunning climbs on the whole island, known locally as “Serenity”. We’ll be breaking this 10km climb down into three distinct sections, kicking off with a block of 6 x 50 second high tempo efforts with a 10 second burst out of the saddle before taking a swift breather before getting back on it. As we climb through the pine forest we’ll switch things up a touch, alternating between low and high cadence for 30 seconds at a time for around 7 minutes. We’ll then revert back to our 50 second high tempo with 10 second burst out of the saddle efforts before we build up our effort to the summit. This is going to be a challenging workout so make sure you’re ready and whatever you do don’t forget to take a moment to look at the views!!

​

This workout combines multiple different interval types that focus on improving threshold power via over-under style efforts along with low cadence work for your muscular endurance. The first and last climbs also fire up your whole energy systems with some sprints to the summit.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/8735613403)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Rue The Day
prospects.description:
Those who have completed SUF icons like Blender, Mini Blender or the Chores will be familiar with the 40-seconds-hard/20-seconds-easy variety of Pain Shakes that Rue the Day delivers in three enticing courses. While the first few efforts in each set will feel "easy," since these blocks are stretched out to 8-minutes in length, you'll be deep into the red by the end of each set.

​

While the efforts aren't continuous, they are long enough that you accumulate plenty of time near your VO2max, which is the goal of any MAP workout. Each 8-minute set gives you more than five minutes at 90% or higher of your 5-minute peak power. By the end, you're looking at 16 minutes of accumulated MAP efforts, so get ready to say 'Hello, Pain!'

Along the way, we'll give you some interesting mental tips on how to prepare for, and better manage, the discomfort (to put it mildly) that comes with such intense efforts. In the end, you'll be both a faster and a mentally stronger cyclist.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Demystifying VO2 and VO2MAX](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/it-takes-vo2-to-tango-demystifying-vo2-and-vo2max)' and '[The Power of Positive Mental Strategies](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/episode-29-how-to-use-positive-self-talk-to-get-through-tough-moments-on-a-ride-mental-strategies)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: Endurance 4.5
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week. Shorter Endurance rides (like this one) can fit in both a hard week of training and a recovery week. That is, only if you do it right!

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70%, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.)

Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm

Also, your RPE should be a 2-3

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 13

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <85%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Sub-Threshold With Surges: 4 x 12
prospects.description:
Yep, there are good chunks of sub-threshold in here. But what makes this session special are the surges above threshold during each effort. Your body's ability to clear metabolites and process oxygen doesn't really change at 90% of FTP and above. What that means it that whether you are at 90% or 100% of FTP your body is clearing those things out at the same rate. It's just that at FTP your body is producing more of those metabolites that it is capable of clearing.

​

By surging above FTP you are creating metabolites faster than your body can clear them. If you were to settle into 100% of FTP, you would only be clearing things out at the rate you are producing them. That means whatever you have produced from that surge will just stay there. By dropping just below FTP your body is clearing things out faster than you are producing them. That means that the excess you got from that surge will slowly be cleared out.

​

Each time a surge pops up during this workout, your body should have just about cleared what was made from the last surge. Not only does this push your body's ability to clear these things to the max, but it also teaches your mind to deal with the discomfort of burning lungs and legs associated with these efforts at or above threshold.

​

A simpler way to think of this is that you are teaching your body and mind to "recover" just below FTP. Not only does this help bump up your FTP, but it also helps you recover that much faster anytime you let off the gas, whether for a downhill, turn, or finding a good draft. Having the confidence that you can recover while feeling so uncomfortable can mean the difference between hanging onto to a new personal best and completely throwing in the towel.

​

This is the perfect session to practice your positive thinking from the Mental Toughness Program (If you haven't checked that out already you definitely should!).

​

**Warm Up**

20 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

1 minute @ RPE 5.5 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <90%

30 seconds @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-180% of FTP)

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 4

Rest between sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per set: 4

**Interval**

Work: 30 seconds @ RPE 8.5 -- 120% of FTP -- HR >105%

Steady: 2 minutes 30 seconds @ RPE 6.5 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <100%

​

**Extra Volume**

25 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Cool Down**

7 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: 04. Getting Positive
prospects.description:
Thoughts matter. To accomplish big goals you need the ability to maintain a positive mindset, regardless of what life gives you. Here's an overview of the power of maintaining a positive mindset. We’ll introduce specific techniques that will help you identify negative thoughts, see obstacles as opportunities, and take a more positive path forward.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: Galicia: Camarinas to Muxia
prospects.description:
It’s time for a wild coastal adventure with your host, Michael Cotty, across some of the stunning undulating roads of Galica, Spain. You’ll start at a historic lighthouse on the ‘Coast of Death’ before working your way deep into the rugged landscape that defines this region. The road will guide your workout, with big efforts up every hill and a chance to take it a bit easier on the descents. It’s not all hard work, though, Mike takes the time to show you around the fishing marina, where to find the ‘hunger herb’ and some of the sights around our finishing village, Muxia.

​

This is a great session for anyone who wants to get in a bit of sprint/anaerobic capacity efforts while laying down some solid aerobic time.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/7392408454)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: The Chores
prospects.description:
If you want a do-it-all session that will maintain and improve nearly every aspect of your fitness, _The Chores_ is just the ticket. This workout features 3 sets of intervals. Each set combines a series of 40-second efforts with 20-second recoveries, followed by an immediate transition to a sustained effort just below threshold. These short efforts with minimal recovery deplete your anaerobic gas tank, forcing your body to get better at producing power aerobically. This combination will help improve your Anaerobic Capacity, (AC) your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and your Functional Threshold Power (FTP), all in just under an hour.

​

At the start of each set, your body starts to dip into your anaerobic reserves to help hit the high-power targets. Your body then starts to ramp up your oxygen intake in order to produce more of the power requirements aerobically. With such short recovery time between these efforts, your AC is steadily drained through each set. By the time the last short interval arrives, your body will be forced to produce almost all of that power aerobically, which will push your lungs to their very limit.

​

This is the optimal time to stress your body’s ability to produce power at threshold. With your AC depleted (and your lungs and heart working near maximal capacity), the shorter sustained efforts that would normally be a piece of cake will have a bit more...sting. No matter what your preferred discipline, terrain, or distance, this session will make you fitter and faster.

​

Featuring exciting, on-bike camera footage from the Velon Hammer Series, _The Chores_ will make you earn your keep.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Endurance 5
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 14

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 1

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Sprints: 18 x 10s
prospects.description:
This is a session that you'll want to complete in Level, rather than Erg, mode. The only time we would suggest Erg mode is if you are unable to maintain the lower power targets set between sprints.

​

With short maximal sprint efforts, you'll recruit every muscle fiber you have in your legs each effort. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal force. Just like cadence builds this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system. Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down effect to the longer duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

​

This session is a great alternate to cadence builds or standing starts for those completing our SUF Strength sessions. On days you complete off the bike strength work you want your on bike training to complement the suffering you put yourself through off the bike. That means short maximal efforts (whether for power or for cadence) are the best workouts to complement the strength gains you've made off the bike.

​

As long as you run this session in slope mode you can complete the sprints either seated or out of the saddle. For those competing in events that do not require much (if any) standing (such as Time Trials or Triathalons) you should complete this sprints seated (and in the aerobars or drops if that is where you are racing).

​

You should also do these efforts seated if you don't feel an out-of-the-saddle maximal sprint is stable/safe to do on your trainer. Regardless of using ERG or Slope mode, you do not want to hold anything back on any sprint. Seeing your peak power drop as the session goes on is totally normal as your legs fatigue. This is where RPE really becomes the most important metric, rather than power, heart rate, or cadence. Now get on that bike and CRUSH IT!

​

**Warm Up **

10 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort **

Number of sets: 18
Rest between sets: 9 minutes 50 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per set: NA

**Interval **

10 seconds @ RPE 10 -- 200% of FTP -- >105%

​

**Extra Volume **

N/A

​

**Cool Down **

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: 06. Relaxing to Recover
prospects.description:
Here you will complete a full Progressive Muscle Relaxation session. It’s part guided meditation and part focus exercise. You should listen to this module at least once per week to get in tune with your body, release tension, and maximize recovery.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: From the Ground Up - Season 1 Pt 1
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Professional Cyclists Alexey Vermeulen and Ryan Petry have documented the

journey of 3 new riders, Roberta, Shawna and Enzo as they prepare to take on the Leadville Trail 100 Mountain Bike Race.

Focusing on education and inclusivity, the series aims to make the sport of cycling less

intimidating and more approachable while inspiring riders of all abilities to take on a challenge of

their own!

​

🚴Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Adventure For All 2023
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023): As one of Wahoo's close partners, Adventure For All's mission is to guide individuals with exceptionalities through life-changing adventures while creating innovative educational practices that ignite a shift in societal belief systems.Together we will guide individuals with exceptionalities through life-changing adventures while creating innovative educational practices that ignite a shift in societal belief systems.

​

**Experience the Adirondacks:**

Join four exceptional athletes in the Adirondack mountains on the adventure of a lifetime. These athletes challenge themselves, conquer fears, and demonstrate their ability to overcome obstacles, proving to themselves and the world they can achieve anything.

​

**Finish:**

Witness Riley, a remarkable young man with Autism and Tourette's, as he pedals beyond expectations to conquer the challenging 31+ mile Big Sugar gravel bike race. This isn't just a story about cycling; it's a journey of courage, hope, and the shattering barriers. With the unwavering support of his mom and the dedicated team at Adventure For All, Riley's adventure redefines what's possible, turning every pedal stroke into a victory for him and everyone who believed in his endless potential.

​

[**Find out more about Adventure For All**](https://adventureforall.org/)

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: 08. Improving Focus
prospects.description:
Develop an understanding of why focused concentration is so important to your performance. We will delve into what it means to be in “The Zone," look at the psychology and the physiology of peak performance, and what it takes to get there.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: Improving Posture
prospects.description: Most cyclists suffer from rounded shoulders and a curved spine as a result of hours spent in the riding position. This series will release tension in your upper back and get you standing up straight and powerful again.

prospects.name: Endurance  3
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

​

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

Warm-Up

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

Main Effort

Number of Sets

8.5

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set

1

Interval: 10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

Extra Volume

N/A

​

Cool Down

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Tempo Increasing: 30/20/10/5min
prospects.description:
In this workout, the shorter the interval duration, the higher the power target will be. Starting from 30 minutes of low Tempo, and finishing with 5-minutes of high-quality MAP work, proper pacing is crucial to success in this workout. While you could easily be above target power for the entire 30-minute effort, that would set you up to fail in the last two efforts. Be smart and pace yourself; you can always go harder in the final 5-minute effort if you want to!

​

At any intensity above Endurance pace, the longer you ride, the more fatigued you become. Completing the final 5-minute target when fresh would be unpleasant, hitting it after all of these other intervals makes it a near maximal effort. Proper hydration/cooling and nutrition are vital if you want to nail this workout.

​

If you are preparing for any longer ride/event where you will be required to keep on the gas from start to finish, this is the perfect session for you. Completing these efforts in this order not only gives a great physical training boost, but it also toughens you up mentally. Digging deep when fatigued is the key to good performance over longer distances, so expect to suffer in that final 5-minute effort; it will pay off both mentally and physically!

​

**Warm Up**

30 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 4, each unique

Rest between sets: 12 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

**Set 1**

30 minutes @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

**Set 2**

3 minutes @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 105% of FTP -- HR <100%

repeat 5 times

**Set 3**

1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 105% of FTP -- HR <100%

8 minutes @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 8.5 -- 120% of FTP -- HR >105%

**Set 4**

1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 105% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 105% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 9.5 -- 180% of FTP -- HR >105%

​

**Extra Volume**

55 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Cool Down**

7 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: 17. Overcoming Obstacles
prospects.description:
Rainbows? Puppy dogs? Not always. Sometimes things go wrong and this session will get you moving again. As a visualization exercise, this module is meant to be listened to whenever you feel stuck—whether that’s due to an obstacle you can’t see a way around, an injury, a loss of motivation, or any other reason which makes you doubt yourself. Even if you don’t have an obstacle right now, it’s a good idea to go through the module so you know what it’s about and when to use it. It will help you re-focus, reset, and reestablish your confidence in who you are and where you’re headed.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: Big Gear MAP: 2 Sets 6 x 30s
prospects.description:
This session is focused on building MAP power at low cadences, which improves muscular endurance. This session includes 2 sets of 6 X 30s intervals at 100% of MAP power with 90s of progressive recovery, building from 50 to 60% of FTP with increasing cadence every 30s.

​

While the efforts have a MAP target, your heart rate will not likely go over Zone 4 due to the short duration of the efforts and even more-so because of the low cadence targets.

​

**Warm Up**

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute 45 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <80%

45 seconds @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 6 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <80%

30 seconds @ RPE 4 -- 70% of FTP -- HR <70%

45 seconds @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <95%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

15 seconds @ RPE 8.5 -- 100% of MAP -- HR >105%

45 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

15 seconds @ RPE 10 -- 110% of MAP -- HR >105%

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 2

Rest Between Sets: 4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval Repeats Per Set: 6

**Interval**

Effort 1: 30 seconds @ RPE 9.5 -- 100% of MAP -- HR>105%

Steady 1: 30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

Steady 2: 30 seconds @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

Steady 3: 30 seconds @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

**Cool Down**

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 1 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 1 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Neck and Upper Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve mobility in the neck, shoulders, upper and mid-back, open up the chest and shoulders and relieve tension at the lower back to help alleviate neck, shoulder, and interscapular pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: From the Ground Up - Season 1 Pt 2
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Roberta, Shawna and Enzo have been training hard for the past 6 months. Share their journey as they arrive in Leadville and take on the Leadville Trail 100 Mountain Bike Race. Focusing on education and inclusivity, the series aims to make the sport of cycling less intimidating and more approachable while inspiring riders of all abilities to take on a challenge of their own!

​

🚴Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: G.O.A.T.
prospects.description:
This session is all about high-torque efforts, very similar to the efforts you would experience riding up the steep slopes of Mt Sufferlandria. While these efforts are short and the intensity isn’t too high, the low cadence targets combined with minimal recovery will leave some begging for the high-cadence sprints of _The Omnium_. High-torque efforts like these have two primary benefits: improved neuromuscular coordination and increased muscular endurance.

​

During each pedal revolution, your legs have to “switch on” and “switch off” almost all of the muscles in your legs. High-cadence efforts in something like _Cadence Builds_ are great for teaching these groups to make that switch quickly. These low-cadence efforts are better for teaching ALL of the muscles in your legs to “switch on.” Done properly, you should be pulling with your hamstrings with one leg while the other leg is pushing down with all the force your glutes and quads can muster. If you feel like you are pushing yourself up out of the saddle during harder efforts (like seated sprints), your hamstrings are not being utilized since they should pull you back down into your saddle.

​

The second main benefit is improved muscular endurance. Even though the session is under 45 minutes, **you'll put a similar amount of muscular fatigue into your legs as a steady, multi-hour base ride.** You can almost view this session as hitting the leg press for 8 sets of 100 reps. And just like the weight room, proper form is absolutely key. That means:

- You should focus on pushing down AND pulling back up. You want your glutes and quads activated on the way down and your hamstring and hip flexors activated on the way up.
- To properly engage your hamstrings think about trying to pulling your heel up to your butt when your crank arm is going from 6 o’clock to 10 o’clock.
- Your knees should be tracking straight up and down, no collapsing in or out.
- Your core should be fully engaged to keep your hips steady in the saddle. This will be easier if you are both pushing and pulling during each pedal revolution.

This session is very similar to _Power Station_. Both help improve your muscular endurance and coordination; the biggest difference is the work to rest ratio between the two. While the intervals here are shorter than those in _Power Station_, the decreased recovery duration means fatigue will build faster, especially for those with a weakness in repeated efforts.

Modifying interval length and recovery duration can also be seen between sessions like _Revolver_ and _A Very Dark Place_. Both serve up a healthy dose of MAP/VO2 work, but the overall feeling of those two sessions is different.

If you find that your lower back starts to ache during this session or that you have to start rocking in the saddle to keep the power up, then it’s time for you to get started on the SYSTM Yoga program. Kick it off with “Core Strengtheners ” to make sure your core is just as strong as those legs.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[When to Train with Low Cadence](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/when-to-train-with-low-cadence)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Endurance  4
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

​

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 11

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 1

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: MAP: 3 x 3
prospects.description:
With a total of only nine minutes spent at or near MAP, this session isn't really designed to push you to your limits (that's what Nine Hammers is for). Instead, it's intended to be used as you begin tapering for an event or test day. While the 3-minute MAP efforts are by no means easy, there are only 3 efforts, with nice long 7-minute recoveries between them. What that means is you will be close to fully recovered at the start of each MAP effort.

Unless you have a substantial VO2 weakness, this session won't do much to help improve your MAP. It will, however, help you maintain your current level. There is just enough sting in this workout to get your system working near its max, but not enough time near your max to add much fatigue. Regardless of what event you are targeting (with the exception of a flying 200m or Kilo on the track) this should be one of your go-to sessions in the final 10 days of your preparation since it primes your cardiovascular system to help you produce power with oxygen more effectively.

​

While ERG mode is great for many workouts, this is one that you might want to run in Level mode, especially if your training has been going well or your Full Frontal results are more than 2 months old. The benefit of this session comes from your body just about hitting its max for the final 10-30 seconds of each effort. Follow the targets set for the first 3-minute interval, and then make any necessary changes to the intensity for the final two.

​

Even though there are cadence targets for each section, you should aim for the same cadence you would hold during the 5-minute test in Full Frontal. The goal is to strike a balance between your cardiovascular system and your muscular system. If your cadence is too low, you will be putting too much stress on your muscular system. Too high and you will be pushing your cardiovascular system more than necessary. If you are relatively fresh, this is how you should feel by the end of each effort:

1. Your heart rate should be above your LTHR.
2. Your breathing rate should be near its max.
3. Your legs should be hurting.

That said, you shouldn't feel like you are turning yourself inside out to make it through the final 30 seconds. Save that feeling for Nine Hammers.

​

**Warm Up**

10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

3 minutes @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

30 seconds @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 150% of FTP -- HR >105%

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Work: 3 minutes @ RPE 9 -- 95-105%% of MAP (115-135% of FTP)

Rest: 7 minute @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Extra Volume**

20 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Cool Down**

10 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: 18. Setting Event Goals
prospects.description:
Get clear on what an event really means to you and what your event-specific goals are.

​

"If you are going to win any battle, you have to do one thing: you have to make the mind run the body."

~ George S. Patton

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Cadence Builds/Holds/Single Leg Drills
prospects.description:
This workout combines several technique-driven intervals. These will improve your overall form and efficiency on the bike. The first two drills, Cadence Holds and Builds, are designed to improve the way you recruit your leg, glute, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke. They do this by forcing you to sustain a cadence just above 'comfortable' and by pushing you to your maximal cadence.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <85%

3 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 4

Rest Between Sets: 8 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval Repeats per Set: 1

**Interval**

Cadence Build: 30 seconds @ RPE 8 -- Starting at 90RPM Build to Max RPM -- Max Power is NOT Goal

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Cadence Hold: 45 seconds @ RPE 7.5 -- <100% FTP -- Highest RPM you can hold without Bouncing

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Single Leg: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- Single Leg Only -- <50% of FTP

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Single Leg: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- Single Leg Only, Opposite Leg -- <50% of FTP (100% of FTP with both legs = 50% of FTP

with one leg)

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

14 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: End Of Day Stretch
prospects.description:
This slow and stretchy sequence is ideal for practicing at the end of a long day at work or after travel. It focuses on opening up the chest and shoulders, stretching the neck and forearms, and releasing tension in the calves, hamstrings, hips, and lower back. These poses can also be used after a workout for a comprehensive full-body stretch.

​

The objectives are to stretch the neck, shoulders, triceps, chest, and forearms; release tension in the lower back, hips, hamstrings, calves, ankles, and feet; transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise; and help alleviate lower and mid back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Puppy
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Ankle Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge Chest Opener
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Tapers
prospects.description:
When it comes to "peaking", or performing at your absolute best on a given day, the key is nailing your Taper. The term "Taper" refers to how you train in the week or so before your target event to ensure you deliver your best performance. Generally, tapering means reducing your total training volume but continuing to hit some high-intensity efforts. While there are individual variations in the best way to taper, this session has been used by countless professionals leading into the biggest races of their lives -- athletes like World Champions Rohan Dennis and Flora Duffy.

​

With 3 sets of micro-intervals (40/20s, 30/30s, and 20/40s) you will hit your system with just enough intensity to keep your legs sharp and responsive, without adding any real fatigue. Outside of those 3 sets of micro-intervals, this session is purposefully short and easy. This is a preparation session, not a training session! After all, your event is just around the corner and all of the important training is behind you. Riding harder or longer today will do absolutely nothing to increase your fitness by event day; in fact, all that would do is increase your fatigue, which will only hurt your performance. Rather, this session makes sure your body is humming along and ready to perform on the big day.

prospects.name: 19. Planning For Every Event Scenario
prospects.description:
Show up prepared by identifying things that could happen during the course of the event and how to deal with them.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: 20. Preparing To Crush It
prospects.description:
This pre-event visualization exercise will help you get in the zone to deliver what athletes and sports psychologists call a “peak performance;” it’s when everything flows and operates at the highest level almost without any effort.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.name: 21. How Did it Go?
prospects.description:
Once the dust has settled and your heart rate has returned to normal levels, listen to this module. It's meant to be completed 15 minutes after the event ends. Part two of this exercise is completed the next day when you’ve had time to process and reflect on everything that happened during the event day.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: Mallorca 312
prospects.description: Put it all together!
